title: Severe Thermal Burns
diagnosis_topic: 40% total body surface area flame burns with inhalation injury
setup_script: A 27-year-old woman is rescued from a house fire. She has deep partial-thickness and full-thickness burns on her torso, arms and face. She is confused and coughing up soot.

dynamic_flow.reply: Singed nasal hairs, carbonaceous sputum and hoarseness; consider early intubation.
BP 110/70 mmHg, HR 120 bpm, RR 26/min, Temp 36.5 C, SpO2 94%.
Approximately 40% TBSA using the rule of nines (anterior torso 18%, both arms 18%, face 4%).

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates fluid resuscitation using Parkland formula
dynamic_flow.reply: 4 mL x 40% x 60 kg = 9.6 L over 24 hours, half in first 8 hours.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident administers IV opioids for pain
dynamic_flow.reply: Pain controlled but vital signs must be monitored closely.
Elevated 25%; start 100% oxygen to treat carbon monoxide poisoning.
Consider for circumferential chest or limb burns impeding ventilation or perfusion.
Transfer for definitive management, debridement and grafting.
Airway edema progresses leading to failed intubation.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about prophylactic antibiotics
dynamic_flow.reply: Systemic prophylaxis not indicated; topical antimicrobials used.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident provides tetanus prophylaxis and addresses nutrition
dynamic_flow.reply: Administer Tdap and discuss high-protein nutritional support.

critical_decision_points: Early airway assessment and management in burn patients
Accurate estimation of burn size and fluid resuscitation using Parkland formula
Management of inhalation injury and carbon monoxide poisoning
Indications for escharotomy and transfer to burn center
Pain control, tetanus prophylaxis and nutritional considerations
